message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about electrical circuits. In order for a light to be turned on, the circuit needs to be complete. This means that there needs to be a continuous path for the electric current to flow from the power source to the light bulb and back to the power source. Option (B) is incorrect because if the light is unplugged, it is not connected to the power source and the circuit is not complete. Option (C) is incorrect because the destruction of the house would likely lead to a loss of power, making it impossible to turn the light on. Option (D) is incorrect because if the power is out, there is no electricity flowing through the circuit, making it impossible to turn the light on.

This question tests knowledge about the basic principles of electrical circuits. In order for a light to be turned on, the circuit must be complete, meaning that there is an unbroken loop for the electric current to flow through. Option (B) is incorrect because if the light is unplugged, there is no connection to the electrical circuit. Option (C) is incorrect because the destruction of a house does not necessarily mean that the electrical circuit is intact. Option (D) is incorrect because if the power is out, there is no electricity flowing through the circuit to power the light.

This question tests basic knowledge of electrical circuits. In order for a light to be turned on, the circuit must be complete. This means that there is a continuous path for the electric current to flow from the power source through the light bulb and back to the power source. Options (B), (C), and (D) all describe situations where the circuit is not complete, so the light would not turn on.

This question revolves around the basic functioning of electrical circuits. A light can be turned on if the circuit is complete, meaning that there is a continuous path for the electric current to flow from the power source to the light bulb and back. Option (B) is incorrect because if the light is unplugged, there is no path for the electric current to flow, so the light will not turn on. Option (C) is not related to the functioning of the light bulb and is unrelated to the question. Option (D) is also incorrect because if the power is out, there is no electricity being supplied to the circuit, so the light will not turn on.

This question requires knowledge about how a light is turned on. Option (A) is correct because in order for a light to turn on, the circuit needs to be complete. This means that there needs to be a closed loop of electrical flow between the power source, the wires, and the light bulb. Option (B) is incorrect because unplugging the light would break the circuit and prevent it from turning on. Option (C) is incorrect because destroying the house would also break the circuit and prevent the light from turning on. Option (D) is incorrect because if the power is out, there is no electricity flowing through the circuit to power the light.

This means that there must be a continuous path for the current to flow from the power source, through the lightbulb, and back to the power source. Option (B) is incorrect because if the light is unplugged, there is no electrical connection and the light cannot be turned on. Option (C) is not related to the functioning of the lightbulb. Option (D) is incorrect because if the power is out, there is no electricity flowing and the light cannot be turned on.
